content.description: At a local elementary school, 35 percent of all students have brown eyes, 45 percent have brown hair, and 60 percent have brown hair or brown eyes. A student will be selected at random from the school. Let <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the event that the selected person has brown eyes, and let <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the event that the selected person has brown hair.
content.question: Are <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> mutually exclusive events?

choices.label: Yes, because <math alttext="the probability of, E intersection H, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because <math alttext="the probability of, E intersection H, equals 0.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because <math alttext="the probability of, E intersection H, equals 0.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.6</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No, because <math alttext="the probability of, E intersection H, equals 0.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No, because <math alttext="the probability of, E intersection H, equals 0.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.6</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: No, because <math alttext="the probability of, E intersection H, equals 0.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
